title: Harry Harlow's Monkey Experiments
description: A micro-lesson that makes Harry Harlow's Monkey Experiments usable.

hook.text: Baby monkeys chose a soft cloth 'mother' over a wire one that gave milk. Comfort beat food every time.

buildup.text: Harry Harlow's 1958 experiments showed that contact comfort â€” not feeding â€” was the basis of attachment.

discovery.text: Monkeys raised without comfort became socially devastated: anxious, aggressive, unable to bond as adults.

twist.text: The experiments were ethically horrifying. They caused tremendous suffering â€” but changed developmental science forever.

climax.text: Harlow proved love isn't abstract. It's physical, measurable, and its absence leaves permanent scars.

punchline.text: Baby monkeys chose comfort over food. So do humans.

quiz.question: What did Harlow's experiments prove about attachment?
options: Contact comfort is more important than feeding
